articles.headline: Lobbying in U.S., Indian Firms Present an American Face
articles.snippet: As the 2008 presidential campaign picks up speed, Indian outsourcing companies have returned to Washington as veritable insiders, slicker and better connected than ever.
articles.abstract: As the 2008 presidential campaign picks up speed, Indian outsourcing companies have returned to Washington as veritable insiders, slicker and better connected than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In the heat of the 2004 presidential race in the United States, John Kerry compared outsourcing to treason, Lou Dobbs harangued against it on CNN and the Indian outsourcing vendors were left scrambling.

articles.headline: Bush, in Iraq, Says Troop Reduction Is Possible
articles.snippet: President Bush pre-empted pressure for a withdrawal by hailing what he called successes and contending that only a stable Iraq would allow a U.S. pullback.
articles.abstract: President Bush pre-empted pressure for a withdrawal by hailing what he called successes and contending that only a stable Iraq would allow a U.S. pullback.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL ASAD AIR BASE, Iraq, Sept. 3 — President Bush made a surprise eight-hour visit to Iraq on Monday, emphasizing security gains, sectarian reconciliation and the possibility of a troop withdrawal, thus embracing and pre-empting this month’s crucial Congressional hearings on his Iraq strategy.
articles.byline: By David S. Cloud and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: A New Push to Regulate Power Costs
articles.snippet: More than a decade after the drive began to convert electricity from a regulated industry into a competitive one, many states are rolling back their initiatives.
articles.abstract: More than a decade after the drive began to convert electricity from a regulated industry into a competitive one, many states are rolling back their initiatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade after the drive began to convert electricity from a regulated industry into a competitive one, many states are rolling back their initiatives or returning money to individuals and businesses.

articles.headline: Before Models Can Turn Around, Knockoffs Fly
articles.snippet: Copying has become so pervasive it is now the No. 1 priority of the Council of Fashion Designers of America.
articles.abstract: Copying has become so pervasive it is now the No. 1 priority of the Council of Fashion Designers of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buyers from the nation’s leading department stores will sift through the work of hundreds of designers as another Fashion Week begins today in New York, seeking the looks that shoppers will want to wear next spring. Seema Anand will be looking for the ones they want right now.

articles.headline: For U.A.W., a Year of Uncertainty
articles.snippet: It still remains unclear whether the United Automobile Workers will agree to the health care overhaul carmakers are seeking.
articles.abstract: It still remains unclear whether the United Automobile Workers will agree to the health care overhaul carmakers are seeking.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Sept. 3 — Detroit’s traditional Labor Day parade took place on Woodward Avenue on Monday with the biggest questions in contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers union and the Detroit automakers yet to be answered, less than two weeks before the pacts expire.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Hardly a Union Hotbed, Toyota’s Kentucky Plant Is a Test for Organizers
articles.snippet: Emboldened by Toyota’s plans to cut labor costs, the United Auto Workers is making its most concerted push yet to organize at the Japanese automaker’s largest American plant.
articles.abstract: Emboldened by Toyota’s plans to cut labor costs, the United Auto Workers is making its most concerted push yet to organize at the Japanese automaker’s largest American plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Ky. — For the last two decades, the United Automobile Workers union has been a constant but largely neutralized presence in this rolling patch of central Kentucky horse country.

articles.headline: Banks to Test Debt Market This Week
articles.snippet: Seven banks try to entice investors to buy $24 billion in loans and bonds to pay for the sale of the First Data Corporation to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
articles.abstract: Seven banks try to entice investors to buy $24 billion in loans and bonds to pay for the sale of the First Data Corporation to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
articles.lead_paragraph: All summer, bankers have sweated on Wall Street. Instead of spending time at the golf course or at their summer houses, many found themselves in the office trying to make sense of the credit market shutdown that had left their companies responsible for the billions of dollars used to finance leveraged buyouts, yet facing uncertain prospects of getting investors to take some of the debt off their hands.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Eric Dash
